WRITING.TEXT:
I agree. Thats why I cited both in that order, I think the EIA's is more reliable.
Good points though.

Yes, thats true. And fossil fuel sources come with massive costs of their own, I cited above. The point is you're missing costs on both sides, fossil fuels for all the damage they do and renewables for variability (and it would be impossible to account for either in an LCOE).
LCOE is still a valid if inperfect comparison. If you're analyzing price, you can furthermore analyze variability separately afterwards.

Germany's electricity prices rose initially about 30%, but [they've been stable since 2013](https://www.statista.com/statistics/418078/electricity-prices-for-households-in-germany/) while their grid has got increasungly clean over that period.
Like I said before, you do need consistent energy. But that can absolutely come in forms other than natural gas or coal.
Most likely, depending on geography. If you live in an area with enough hydropower you can get away with that as well.

Actually a lot closer than you think!
Here is [Lazards Storage 1.0](https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-storage-analysis-10/) analysis. Here is their [2.0 Analysis a year later](https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-storage-analysis-20/). 2 things to note.
1) Lithium ion went down from 347-739 to 267-561. Thats a massive drop for one year.
2) More importantly, lithium ion is approaching the cost levels of pumped hydro and compressed air. Those sources are already cheap enough to be somewhat widely used. So my guess is big storage could be a as little as 2 years away.

I would say you need some form of consistent energy. In the future, storage may be the answer.
Right now, yes that list is close to accurate (probably throw geothermal on there as well).

Yeah, a number of countries are pretty much there. Usually those with good hydro resources or pre-existing reliance on nuclear.
I just don't like the myth propogated that you *need* coal/natural gas. We have other sources of energy.

Here is the Wikipedia page [on this](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life-cycle_greenhouse-gas_emissions_of_energy_sources?wprov=sfla1).
Wind's footprint is roughly 2% of the footprint of natural gas, little over 1% of coal. Solar is a little more, but still far better.
Part of this is also a chicken and egg problem. Takes electricity to make them, electricity that comes from coal/natural gas. But until we make them, electricity has to come from coal/natural gas.

With that being said, take a look at [EIA LCOE](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_electricity_by_source?wprov=sfla1) or [Lazard LCOE](https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-energy-analysis-100/). Renewables are fully competitive with natural gas today, even with absolutely no subsidies.
I do agree, fossil fuels are a neccesity right now, its only realistic. But I think what gets lost is the additional [costs of not acting as well](http://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21605936-scorched-farms-flooded-homes-and-lower-productivity-cost-doing-nothing).
You're right. Higher electricity prices have their consequences. But it has been shown that [not acting probably has more](http://www.ucsusa.org/global_warming/solutions/reduce-emissions/economics-climate-factsheet.html#.WPRqsCIanqA). Its more than just environmental factors, thats the fundamental misconception. Its economic and health factors.
Coal is estimated to cost [roughly $500 Billion annually](https://www.fastcompany.com/1727949/coal-costs-us-500-billion-annually-health-economic-environmental-impacts) in health, economic, and environmental costs in the US alone. Natural gas is better, but not good enough. Its about 50% cleaner, so it will still cost a very substantial amount.
It would also be very inaccurate to say you need LNG/lignite for when the winds not blowing. Many countries actually already use no or almost no fossil fuels ([Sweden is a good example](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Sweden?wprov=sfla1)). There are lots of alternatives other than natural gas or coal, primarily nuclear but hydropower and associated storage works very well too in certain places, like Costa Rica.
EDIT: I should add I think you made good points. Just trying to add additional context.

WRITING.TITLE: My thoughts on the game
WRITING.TEXT:
So, first things first: **fucking brutal**. It caused me pain to watch them play. I've seen junior high teams with more poise and grace.
But some notes:
- Kyle Lowry didn't look like himself. Can't help but wonder if the flu-like symptoms aren't bothering him.
- Its not all Caseys fault. But it is a little. Guys weren't hitting shots. Casey can't fix that. But how do Kyle and Cory combine for 60 minutes and 7 points, and not even give Delon a try? Could he do anything worse? Probably my biggest pet peeve with Casey, when somethings not working, he doesn't adjust. But its not the reason we lost.
- DeRozan looked okay, but he can't haul this offense all by himself. By the 4th quarter, the Bucks basically stopped guarding everyone else.
- We need more than 4 from Lowry. All there is to it.
- At the end of the day, the issue is right here: 36/22/73. Its really that simple.
EDIT: Grammar

[Here's a citation if you want to check it out](https://www.populationmatters.org/documents/reducing_emissions.pdf).
Lol, yeah. Literally almost every country in the world has debt, that's completely normal (the 5 that don't are Macao, British Virgin Islands, Brunei, Liechenstein, and Palau).
Well, helping to fund contraception and abortion will help, absolutely. Of course it will. I think its actually a pretty worthy cause, we can fight overpopulation and combat climate change at the same time. We aren't going to solve overpopulation entirely all by ourselves, but that doesn't mean we can't do a ton of good and make a good contribution.

I'm okay with a little bit of our money going towards foreign aid.
We're one of the wealthiest countries on Earth with one of the highest standards of living. Despite all our whining, we are extraordinarily well off. When we send money to poor countries, it can do an extraordinary amount of good. It can save a lot of lives in countries that aren't as lucky as we are. Honestly, it can do way more good than it can here.

Yeah, but that statement was fucking ridiculous.
As if the developings worlds main problem is *not enough free market*. No, not corruption, poverty, war, instability, or anything else of the like. Its just not enough free market!

Overpopulation is also a huge and very serious issue.
A recent study even said that money towards fighting overpopulation was a *very* cost-effective method of fighting climate change.
EDIT: [Study here](https://www.populationmatters.org/documents/reducing_emissions.pdf).
No. But he let it go public. Ignorance does not excuse incompetence. Its equally as stupid if he didn't write the line.

Precisely. I agree totally.
Even if he opposes a carbon tax, fine. I just can't stand for total bullshit like this.

Yet, that S-Class owner did buy a Tesla. And liked it. But most S-Class owners probably wouldn't buy a Tesla. They're marketed and designed to far different crowds.
Both tests scored Tesla better? Thats not even arguable. Go look at them. The one actually called the S-Class system a total disaster, not even close to Autopilot.
I think most people would agree the S Class interior is better. But how can you stick your head in the sand about all of the advantages of a Tesla? Far better autonomous driving? Faster acceleration? Those two are really unarguable. Not everyone places interior aesthetics above all like you do.
For what reason do you think tens of thousands of people are spending comparable money on a Tesla if its a way worse vehicle? Just cause?

No, not particuarly. Most people would say a 400 to 540 Km range is enough to do what they want, including myself. So what does "more range" mean at that point? To me, very little. Having more provides no real advantage.
[Here is a Tesla and Mercedes S owner comparing the two](https://forums.tesla.com/en_CA/forum/forums/tesla-s85-vs-mercedes-s550). He gives edges to both (Tesla: technology, noise, acceleration, speed. Mercedes: luxury, comfort, ease of entering).
Here is a comparison of [their self-driving](http://www.caranddriver.com/features/semi-autonomous-cars-compared-tesla-vs-bmw-mercedes-and-infiniti-feature-the-physiology-of-semi-autonomy-and-test-results-page-6) from Car and Driver. It was actually a $250,000 Mercedes S vs a $136,000 Tesla, so hardly a fair test but Tesla scored better anyways.

This comparison from [US News](https://cars.usnews.com/cars-trucks/compare?trims=12593-364388_12617-366454) has them very comparable. 9.6 critic rating for the S-Class, 9.5 for the Tesla.
I really can't see how you can pretend the Mercedes is a far better, clearly superior car. Both have advantages and disadvantages. Not saying the Tesla is objectively *better*, but comparable? Absolutely.

[Check here too](http://www.carsdirect.com/green-cars/how-reliable-is-an-electric-car-engine) then.
Relevant quote: "It's the moving parts in a regular gasoline or diesel engine that tend to fail over time and can include anything from the pistons to the belts. The great advantage of an electric car engine is that it has no moving parts so these cannot actually fail.".
Now it does note that other parts of EV's can fail, and that's true, but it'll take some more time to see how severe these issues look like. But overall it very much looks like EV's should be considerably more reliable. Sadly, we just haven't had enough EV's on the road yet to get a good subset of data so I'll be looking forward to some bigger sample sizes to look at. They may face some issues in the beginning as the technology is still young and more break-prone, but in the long run I definitely think they'll prove to be far more reliable.

WRITING.TITLE: Whats a 3-Phase power line?
WRITING.TEXT:
I know, probably a stupid question. But I was told to find a site near a 3-phase powerline for a solar farm.
How do I tell if a line is a 3-phase?
I [found this](http://powerforthefuture.ca/electricity-411/electricity-map/) map but the legend doesn't define 3 phase transmission line. Is a 230+ kV system the same as a 3 - phase transmission line?
Thanks so much for the help!
Hmm...tough one. Probably D,1,C,K.
The Model 3, yes. It would be the mid range. The S and X are high end luxury vehicles. Model 3 is similiarly priced to the Chevy Bolt for example.
Model Y, same platform as the Model 3 but an SUV.

Thats why you set limits though, Colorado uses 5 nanograms.
The technology is far from perfect. But its probably the most accurate we have. Canada is breaking ground on this issue, so we'll have to try and determine the best way. Its going to be largely trial and error.
Saskatchewan is going to hammer the shit out of this legislation.

Yeah, its a tough issue. They do need a method of enforcement that actually works. At the same time, they need heavy oversight because too many of these private lots are known for doing unscrupulous things (I've seen it a couple times around my area in downtown Edmonton).
I think ticketing is probably the better way to go, but they need to be able to actually enforce the tickets then. The reason I don't like boots is because if they do unfairly boot someone, that persons basically stuck. Even if there was a way to appeal, it would probably take hours to days or longer. Meanwhile, you lose use of your vehicle for that time and you have to find another means of transportation.
Either way, hopefully they actually deal with this and find a real solution.

Not true at all!
You have to realize what the Tesla vehicles are. They're luxury vehicles (so far at least). The Model S doesn't compete against $25,000 Mazdas. It competes against the BMW 7 Series, and for that it is very competitively priced. The Model 3 competes against the 3 Series/A4/Mercedes C.
If he could break into that segment, it would be amazing.

Yes and no. The first thing to note is you're refering to long-haul semis. Not all semis go such crazy distances, so my guess is you would start out with either semis used for short hauls or in yards (there are actually already some electric semis being used for this).
We'll see what range looks like, but electric semis also have big advantages. Mainly, they are *way* cheaper to run. So you can afford to spend more time stopped and charging if you can run the vehicle much cheaper. That could let them get away with somewhat shorter ranges hopefully.
Anyhow, it will be an interesting expirment none the less.
EDIT: Guys, don't downvote him. He raised some good concerns and questions. I'm glad this got brought up.

They also also almost no oversight and appeal process though, unlike the city.
I see what you mean, but I'm also skeptical because of how much shady shit the private lots pull. Basically your only recourse is to sue them, which isn't realistic for the majority of people.
